How is the Eco-Score calculated?
Life cycle assessment (LCA)
Life cycle analysis a standardized assessment method for carrying out a multi-stage environmental assessment and multi-criteria:

Eat less meat but of better quality
Consume more organic products and products with quality labels
Favor local and seasonal products, with little packaging
Limit products containing problematic ingredients (endangered fish, unsustainable palm oil)

The Eco-Score is designed on a model similar to the Nutri-Score: it is a grade from A to E which summarizes 15 environmental impacts. The Eco-Score score is materialized by a colored leaf-shaped logo with a letter from A (very low impact) to E (very high impact).

6 production steps: agriculture, processing, packaging, transportation, distribution and consumption 14 environmental impact indicators: climate change/carbon footprint, ozone layer depletion, ionizing radiation, land, water, and energy use; pollution of air and marine and fresh water (particles, acidification, eutrophication); and depletion of resources.
Nova groups for food processing
What is NOVA and how are UPF defined?

The NOVA score measures the level of processing of foods on a scale of 1 “minimally-processed” to 4 “ultra-processed.” Studies have shown that NOVA-4 foods contribute disproportionately to weight gain. For a healthy diet, it is generally recommended to minimize the amount of NOVA-4 foods.

Group 1 - Unprocessed or minimally processed foods
Group 2 - Processed culinary ingredients
Group 3 - Processed foods
Group 4 - Ultra-processed food and drink products
A classification in 4 groups to highlight the degree of processing of foods

Basically, the nutritional value for the Nutri-Score letter grade is determined by subtracting the total positive points from the total negative points. And the lower the score, the better the letter grade.
